author: By Daisuke Wakabayashi
title: Google delays its return to office until January.
description: It is the latest company to push back plans for a return in light of the spread of the highly contagious Delta variant of the coronavirus.
content: Google is pushing back its return-to-office date by three months, to Jan. 10, in a decision that reflects the spread of the highly contagious Delta variant of the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: 70 Years After Being Executed for Rape, 7 Black Men Are Pardoned in Virginia
description: For decades, family members of the men, known as the Martinsville Seven, contended that they were denied due process. Gov. Ralph S. Northam agreed.
content: Seven Black men who were executed 70 years ago for the rape of a white woman were posthumously pardoned on Tuesday by Virginia’s governor, who said that the group, known as the Martinsville Seven, was denied due process because of race.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Troy Closson
title: R. Kelly Got Angry if Women Broke His Rules, Ex-Assistant Says
description: Five accusers — four women and one man — have now testified that the singer had sexual contact with them when they were underage, including a woman who described being raped.
content: One of R. Kelly’s former assistants described the singer’s system of strict rules for the women in his orbit — and the anger he displayed when those rules were broken.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hiroko Tabuchi
title: The storm hit one of the country’s biggest oil and chemical hubs.
description: The most intense hurricane on record to strike Louisiana swept through one of the nation’s largest chemical, petroleum and natural gas hubs. And while it may take days or weeks for the full extent of the storm’s impact to become clear, early reports of damage have heightened concerns over the vulnerability of the region’s fossil fuel infrastructure to intensifying storms.
content: The most intense hurricane on record to strike Louisiana swept through one of the nation’s largest chemical, petroleum and natural gas hubs. And while it may take days or weeks for the full extent of the storm’s impact to become clear, early reports of damage have heightened concerns over the vulnerability of the region’s fossil fuel infrastructure to intensifying storms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Clare Toeniskoetter, Annie Brown, Stella Tan, Paige Cowett and Marion Lozano
title: America’s Final Hours in Afghanistan
description: After a 20-year war, the United States has completed its withdrawal. How did it happen and what’s next?
content: On Monday night, after a 20-year war that claimed 170,000 lives, cost over $2 trillion and did not defeat the Taliban, the United States completed its withdrawal from Afghanistan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pete Wells
title: A Sushi Hideaway Where There’s Always Something New to Taste
description: A meal at Nakaji might start with icefish and end with watermelon. Then, if you can afford it, try a $300 shot of whiskey.
content: Try to get a reservation at one of Manhattan’s luxury sushi bars and you’d never guess that the restaurant business is struggling. As I write this, you need to wait a week to experience one of Shion Uino’s $420 omakase meals at 69 Leonard Street. Masa, where lunch and dinner are now $800 a person, is almost fully booked for the next two weeks. At Sushi Noz, spots at both the counter of buffed hinoki wood, where dinner is $400, and the secondary bar made of ash, where it costs $225, are all but sold out for the next month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ashley Wong
title: Teenage Lifeguard Killed in Lightning Strike: ‘It Was Like a Bomb’
description: Keith Pinto was working at a beach on the Jersey Shore when lightning struck, killing him and injuring other lifeguards and beachgoers.
content: A teenage lifeguard was killed and at least seven other people were injured in a lightning strike Monday on a New Jersey beach.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andy Horowitz
title: Hurricane Ida Offers a Glimpse of the Dystopia That’s Coming for All of Us
description: Louisiana is no longer an outlier.
content: As a boy, Louis Armstrong worked for the Karnofsky family. The Karnofskys’ tailor shop on South Rampart Street in New Orleans became a second home to him, and the family helped him buy his first cornet. On Sunday night, the Karnofsky building, long neglected by the city and a succession of private owners who promised to restore it, finally collapsed under the force of Hurricane Ida’s winds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer
title: Ukraine’s Leader, Meeting Biden, Seeks Security Assurances After Afghan Pullout
description: President Volodymyr Zelensky is expected to emphasize the important role Ukraine plays in containing Russia, aides to the Ukrainian leader said.
content: MOSCOW — Unnerved by America’s abrupt and chaotic withdrawal from Afghanistan, the president of Ukraine, Volodymyr Zelensky, is expected to raise questions about U.S. security commitments when he meets President Biden on Wednesday, an adviser to the Ukrainian leader said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Huylebroek, Najim Rahim and Eric Nagourney
title: The Taliban Celebrate Victory, With a Crisis Looming
description: With the final U.S. troops gone, triumphant scenes were clouded by the prospect of famine and financial collapse. The Taliban spokesman called for international engagement.
content: KABUL, Afghanistan — The Taliban celebrated a complete victory on Tuesday, achieving a goal they had nurtured through two decades: the exit of the last U.S. soldier from Afghanistan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reed Abelson
title: Loopholes Leave Gaps in Mandated Coverage for Mental Health
description: Health plans for state and local workers can opt out of the federal law requiring them to treat mental health like other medical conditions.
content: One 16-year-old spent 28 days in treatment for substance abuse but was forced to leave once his parents’ insurance coverage ran out.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Transcript of Biden’s Speech on the U.S. Withdrawal From Afghanistan
description: A day after U.S. troops left, the president called the mission to evacuate Americans and Afghan allies an “extraordinary success” and forcefully defended ending the United States’ involvement.
content: The following is a transcript of President Biden’s remarks about Afghanistan on Tuesday, a day after the United States concluded its two-decade war there with the end of evacuation flights and the departure of the last American troops.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: Naomi Osaka, happy to play for a crowd, wins her first-round match.
description: Osaka navigated a challenging first set before settling in and beating Marie Bouzkova of the Czech Republic 6-4, 6-1.
content: Naomi Osaka had a solid start to the defense of her U.S. Open title, posting a 6-4, 6-1 win over Marie Bouzkova of the Czech Republic that was a little closer than the final score suggested.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dror Poleg
title: The Winners of Remote Work
description: There are already examples of how gains are captured by the few and not the many.
content: Who wins and who loses when companies can hire from anywhere?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Collins-Hughes and Erik Tanner
title: They Finally Get to Dance on Broadway
description: These young dancers have Broadway debuts in store when the industry reopens. Some of them have been waiting more than a year to show their stuff.
content: No one but her puppy, Alfie, was with Ayla Ciccone-Burton when she heard the good news from her agent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noah Weiland and Sharon LaFraniere
title: Two Top F.D.A. Vaccine Regulators Are Set to Depart During a Crucial Period
description: The announcement that Dr. Marion Gruber and Dr. Philip Krause will leave this fall comes as the agency conducts sensitive reviews of coronavirus vaccines for children and booster shots.
content: WASHINGTON — Two of the Food and Drug Administration’s top vaccine regulators will leave the agency this fall, a development that could disrupt its work on deciding whether to recommend coronavirus vaccines for children under 12 and booster shots for the general population.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Sarah Kessler, Stephen Gandel, Lauren Hirsch, Ephrat Livni and Anna Schaverien
title: Elizabeth Holmes on Trial
description: The Theranos founder’s day in court is approaching.
content: Jury selection begins today in the federal criminal case against Elizabeth Holmes, the founder of the blood-testing tech start-up Theranos. Indicted in 2018, she faces a dozen counts of fraud and conspiracy to commit wire fraud for making false claims about Theranos’s blood tests and business prospects. She has pleaded not guilty. If convicted, Holmes, 37, faces up to 20 years in prison.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Iowa Farmworker Gets Life in Prison for the Murder of Mollie Tibbetts
description: Cristhian Bahena Rivera was convicted in May in the 2018 fatal stabbing of Ms. Tibbetts, which Donald J. Trump used to stoke opposition to illegal immigration.
content: A farmworker was sentenced on Monday to life in prison without the possibility of parole in the fatal stabbing of an Iowa college student in 2018, a crime that Donald J. Trump seized upon as president as he amplified his hard-line policies against illegal immigration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carol Rosenberg
title: Charges in Bali Bombing Case Are Delayed at Guantánamo
description: The three prisoners were to be charged for the first time, 18 years after their capture. Translation problems mean they wait one more day.
content: GUANTÁNAMO BAY, Cuba — Translation and interpretation problems on Monday delayed by one day military efforts to formally charge three Southeast Asian men — held by the United States for 18 years — with conspiring in deadly terrorist bombings in Indonesia in 2002 and 2003.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Caramanica
title: Kanye West’s ‘Donda’ Era, on a Chaotic Stage
description: West is still one of the most influential pop stars of the century, but multidisciplinary spectacle is more his goal than music now, and he isn’t the star of his own 10th album.
content: For the last few years, Kanye West — perhaps tired of the insufficiency of the album, or music-making in general — has been seeking increasingly grand canvases for his various projects. There was the 2016 Yeezy Season 3 fashion show and album debut held at Madison Square Garden. His Imax film, “Jesus Is King,” filmed in James Turrell’s land art installation Roden Crater, in Arizona. A domed prototype for affordable housing built on his property in Calabasas, Calif. A vast expanse of ranch outside Cody, Wyo., annexed for work and play.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Jakes
title: Stranded in Kabul: A U.S. Resident Runs Out of Options
description: Refugee groups say hundreds, and possibly thousands, of green card holders have been left behind.
content: WASHINGTON — For more than a week, Samiullah Naderi, a U.S. legal permanent resident, waited days and nights with his wife and son outside the airport in Kabul, Afghanistan, hoping to be let in so that they could leave on one of the dozens of daily flights headed to America.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: Joe Biden’s Critics Lost Afghanistan
description: Our stumbling withdrawal was bad. The decades of waste and quagmire were much worse.
content: A month ago I thought I was a cynic about our 20-year war in Afghanistan. Today, after watching our stumbling withdrawal and the swift collapse of practically everything we fought for, my main feeling is that I wasn’t cynical enough.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vimal Patel
title: Trail in Decades-Old Florida Killings Leads to Brazilian Man
description: Roberto Wagner Fernandes, who died in a plane crash in Paraguay in 2005, killed three women whose bodies were found in Miami and Broward County in 2000 and 2001, the authorities said.
content: A man who died in a plane crash in Paraguay in 2005 was responsible for the deaths of three women whose killings in South Florida remained unsolved for two decades, the authorities said Tuesday, citing advances in crime-scene technology and years of detective work across two continents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alisha Haridasani Gupta
title: Lessons on Child Care, From the Military
description: The military transformed what was once an underfunded, scattershot child care system into one of the best in the country. Some see it as a model to emulate.
content: — New York Times article about military child care from 1975
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Will Dudding
title: Afghanistan, Texas, Kanye West: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karan Deep Singh
title: India’s Economic Figures Belie Covid-19’s Toll
description: Strong results compared with last year’s performance mask lingering weaknesses that could hold back needed job creation.
content: NEW DELHI — The coronavirus continues to batter India’s damaged economy, putting growing pressure on Prime Minister Narendra Modi to nurture a nascent recovery and get the country back to work.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: Go-to Lawyer for Capitol Riot Defendants Disappears
description: John Pierce has been a combative advocate for those accused of participating in the Jan. 6 attack, but he’s missed court appearances for a week.
content: The mysterious disappearance of the lawyer John Pierce began last Tuesday, prosecutors say, when he missed a hearing for one of the many cases where he is representing a defendant in the Capitol riot investigation. The young associate who took his place said that Mr. Pierce had a “conflict.” At the time, no one seemed to give it much mind.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Maslin Nir
title: The Cocaine Was Laced With Fentanyl. Now Six Are Dead From Overdoses.
description: The deaths over three days in Suffolk County reflect a dangerous shift in the street-drug marketplace, according to police and prosecutors.
content: SOUTHOLD, N.Y. — The 911 calls to the Southold Town Police Department began to pour in on a Wednesday. And for three days they did not stop.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: To Play Tennis, Naomi Osaka Finds a New Purpose. So Far, So Good.
description: The defending champion started the U.S. Open with a solid 6-4, 6-1 win over Marie Bouzkova, a hard-hitting Czech. Feeling good about herself is the next challenge.
content: Naomi Osaka was back on the tennis court in New York on Monday night, not far from where she first started hitting a tennis ball in earnest as a child, and where her year of years began 12 months and what seems like a lifetime ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Fabi
title: A Cut Above
description: Eric Bornstein must be hungry.
content: TUESDAY PUZZLE — Congratulations to Eric Bornstein, who is making his fifth appearance in the New York Times Crossword this year alone, and his seventh altogether in just over a year. Now that is a cut above!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Max Gendler
title: 2021 U.S. Open: What to Watch on Tuesday
description: Novak Djokovic and Ashleigh Barty feature on Arthur Ashe Stadium as a slew of young talent battles on the grounds of Flushing Meadows.
content: How to watch: From noon to 6 p.m. Eastern on ESPN; 7 to 11 p.m. on ESPN2; and streaming on the ESPN app.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caity Weaver
title: In the Kitchens of the Rich, Things Are Not as They Seem
description: Good luck finding the ice.
content: The kitchens of the wealthy in the United States today are capable of providing a humbling experience to the uninitiated. Attempts to procure ice cubes can transform the most dignified guest into a hapless burglar rummaging through drawers for loose gems.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Wilson
title: The Stenographer Who Married Dostoyevsky — and Saved Him From Ruin
description: “The Gambler Wife,” by Andrew D. Kaufman, recounts the life of Anna Dostoyevskaya, the Russian writer’s second wife, who took dictation of his books, endured his gambling addiction and eventually published his work herself.
content: THE GAMBLER WIFEA True Story of Love, Risk, and the Woman Who Saved Dostoyevsky By Andrew D. Kaufman
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azi Paybarah
title: Inside Kabul airport, the last American soldier leaves, and the first Taliban fighters arrive.
description: Two images marked the end of the nearly 20-year war: a U.S. soldier leaving Kabul’s airport, and Taliban fighters nearby walking in.
content: The last moments of the U.S. occupation of Afghanistan were captured in two images that were a reversal of the American invasion nearly 20 years ago: A U.S. soldier leaving as Taliban fighters took control.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Satariano and Mike Isaac
title: The Silent Partner Cleaning Up Facebook for $500 Million a Year
description: The social network has constructed a vast infrastructure to keep toxic material off its platform. At the center of it is Accenture, the blue-chip consulting firm.
content: In 2019, Julie Sweet, the newly appointed chief executive of the global consulting firm Accenture, held a meeting with top managers. She had a question: Should Accenture get out of some of the work it was doing for a leading client, Facebook?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ashley Wong
title: How Sasha the Cougar Was Rescued From a Bronx Home
description: The wild animal was taken to the Bronx Zoo and then moved to a sanctuary in Arkansas.
content: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Saif Hasnat and Suhasini Raj
title: 6 Sentenced to Death in Bangladesh for Killing of Gay Rights Activist
description: The activist Xulhaz Mannan, who had started a gay, lesbian, bisexual and transgender magazine, was hacked to death in a machete attack in 2016.
content: DHAKA, Bangladesh — Six men said to belong to an Islamist militant group were convicted and sentenced to death on Tuesday over the 2016 killings of a prominent Bangladeshi gay rights activist and his friend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein
title: Thumbs Way Up: Javier Baez Wins Mets Fans Back With Hustle
description: Baez and Francisco Lindor asked for forgiveness for their thumbs-down gestures. More important to fans: The team won both games of a doubleheader.
content: It began with a pair of apologies, ended with a couple of wins and the only thing the Mets and Javier Baez lost on Tuesday was an earring.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Ezra Klein Show'
title: My Reading Habits, Explained, and Other Questions You Asked
description: Ezra Klein responds to what listeners want to know.
content: We asked for your questions, and you answered. Hundreds and hundreds of fantastic questions poured in, and our producer Annie Galvin joined me to ask some of the best of them. Does the infrastructure bill mean there’s more hope for bipartisanship than we thought? What’s my view on the degrowth movement? What do I think my book, “Why We’re Polarized,” got right, and what did it get wrong? Will plant- and cell-based meats ever be cheaper than eating animals, given the subsidies the meat industry gets? Why hasn’t any blue state created a single-payer health care system? Can you really build more housing without creating a biodiversity crisis?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coral Davenport
title: Federal Judge Strikes Down Trump Rule Governing Water Pollution
description: The rule allowed fertilizers, pesticides and industrial chemicals to flow into small streams, marshes and wetlands. The judge warned of environmental harm.
content: WASHINGTON — A federal judge on Monday struck down a Trump-era environmental rule that drastically limited federal restrictions against pollution of millions of streams, wetlands and marshes across the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luis Ferré-Sadurní
title: N.Y. Legislature Expected to Extend Freeze on Evictions in Rare Special Session
description: The moratorium, which was to expire on Aug. 31, is part of the state’s effort to help tenants struggling from the effects of the coronavirus pandemic.
content: With New York’s eviction moratorium about to expire, the State Legislature will reconvene for an extraordinary session on Wednesday to extend the pandemic-era ban on evictions, a move that would protect tens of thousands of tenants.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Imbler
title: How Scorpion Tails Do the Bend and Twist
description: It remains unknown if this move has an 83 percent return on a dinner invitation.
content: In a nail salon in Los Angeles, Elle Woods introduced a nail technician named Paulette to the bend and snap: a foolproof method of catching someone’s attention, and the only move that has an 83 percent return on a dinner invitation, at least in the universe of the “Legally Blonde” films.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo
title: A Fellini Museum, as Lavish as His Movies
description: The exhibition spaces, which recently opened in Rimini, celebrate one of Italy’s most famous directors. But to some citizens, it puts tourism over local needs.
content: RIMINI, Italy — Federico Fellini is one of a select group of movie directors to have gotten an Oxford English Dictionary-sanctioned adjective: “Felliniesque,” which is defined as “fantastic, bizarre; lavish, extravagant.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: What Does Black Love Mean to You?
description: Share your personal stories — funny, sad and everything in between — about Black love.
content: In her 1968 poem, “Nikki-Rosa,” Nikki Giovanni wrote: “they never understand / Black love is Black wealth and they’ll / probably talk about my hard childhood / and never understand that / all the while I was quite happy.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Why Are So Many Government Positions Still Vacant?
description: The problem is not unique to the Biden administration, said the head of a nonpartisan group that tracks vacancies.
content: One of the running criticisms of the Trump administration was how slowly it nominated and won confirmation for hundreds of high-level government officials, especially in critical agencies like the State Department and the Department of Homeland Security.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Rosenzweig
title: There’s a Better Way to Stop Ransomware Attacks
description: We’re not tackling the problem at its root.
content: Ransomware attacks are plaguing the United States. With alarming regularity, cybercriminals disrupt computer systems controlling important pieces of infrastructure and refuse to restore access until they are paid — typically in Bitcoin or another decentralized, hard-to-trace cryptocurrency.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer
title: European Court Faults Russia in High-Profile Murder Case
description: The European Court of Human Rights ruled that Russia failed to investigate the abduction and murder of Natalya Estemirova, a human rights researcher, but did not directly implicate the state in her killing.
content: MOSCOW — The European Court of Human Rights on Tuesday faulted Russia’s government for failing to investigate the abduction and assassination a decade ago of one of the country’s most prominent human rights defenders, Natalya Estemirova.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jin Yu Young
title: South Korea forces Google and Apple to allow third-party in-app payments.
description: The law, the first of its kind in the world, deals a blow to the market dominance of the tech giants, which opposed the bill.
content: South Korea legislators on Tuesday approved the first law in the world that requires app stores to let users pay for in-app purchases through multiple payment systems, a blow to the market dominance of Apple and Google, which opposed the bill.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giulia Heyward
title: There were flash floods, strong winds and at least two deaths in Mississippi.
description: The deaths came after the storm washed away part of a highway.
content: While Louisiana bore the brunt of Ida, the storm also cut into Mississippi as a powerful hurricane, toppling trees, bringing down power lines and washing away part of a highway, causing at least two deaths.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Fausset, Katy Reckdahl, Campbell Robertson and Tariro Mzezewa
title: Louisiana Residents Who Fled Before Ida Are Urged to Stay Away Indefinitely
description: New Orleans, which is introducing a curfew, remains without electricity. Hundreds of thousands have no water.
content: NEW ORLEANS — As hundreds of thousands of people in Louisiana faced the prospect of punishingly hot weeks ahead without electricity, officials urged those who had fled before the onslaught of Hurricane Ida to stay away indefinitely as the long slog of recovery began.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kristen Bayrakdarian
title: Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions
description: Recent commercial real estate transactions in New York.
content: $6.3 MILLION
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘Three Rooms,’ by Jo Hamya: An Excerpt
description: An excerpt from “Three Rooms,” by Jo Hamya
content: Sink and unframed mirror. The southwest corner of the room. My phone, propped up between the faucet and the wall, and my lips in the mirror, and my fingers doing their little tap, tap over them with a tissue, blotting lipstick. All to the sound of my mother: Do we think that dress is the right choice for a work party, and my mother, Did you make sure they got the inventory form, and my mother, Are you making friends, and my mother, I miss you, when will you come home? The soft little worries running alongside the tap. I let them go down the plughole. It wasn’t enough. Some aspect of them stayed, as though they’d filtered from the faucet into the glass of water I’d had before leaving for the meet and greet. I got lost on the way to the English faculty and ended up late.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Max Fisher
title: The New U.S. Challenge in Afghanistan: Coping With Taliban Rule
description: Its longtime enemy now a fact of life, Washington must choose when to shun or tolerate the group, with all the wrenching trade-offs each policy choice brings.
content: Even as the United States finalizes its departure from Afghanistan, it faces a dilemma there as wrenching as any during the 20-year war: how to deal with the new Taliban government.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: James Whiteside Thinks ‘The Legend of Zelda’ Would Make a Great Ballet
description: The American Ballet Theater dancer discusses the beauty of anime soundtracks, the virtue of late ’90s music videos and playing video games backstage.
content: It is 1:30 a.m., and James Whiteside, a principal dancer with the American Ballet Theater, is curled up in an Airbnb in London watching “Clash of the Titans.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Transcript of Blinken’s Speech on ‘New Chapter’ in Afghanistan
description: Shortly after the last U.S. troops left Afghanistan, the secretary of state outlined a plan to use diplomacy to try to extract remaining Americans and Afghan allies.
content: The following is a transcript of Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken’s remarks on Monday about the U.S. plan for engagement with Afghanistan after evacuations ended and the last American troops departed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: Bank of England Removes Art of Leaders Linked to Slave Trade
description: Oil paintings and portraits depicting seven leading figures at the bank have been removed because of their connections to slavery.
content: LONDON — The Bank of England has stopped displaying art depicting several former governors and directors after a review found they were connected to the trans-Atlantic slave trade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Goldberg
title: The Intolerable Wait for a Kids’ Vaccine
description: As children’s hospital beds fill up, the F.D.A. shouldn’t delay.
content: Julie Swann, an engineer who studies health systems and models infectious disease at North Carolina State University, leads a team of researchers who recently tried to simulate how the Delta variant of the coronavirus could move through schools in various scenarios. The results, which The Washington Post published over the weekend, were alarming.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel E. Slotnik
title: Pennsylvania’s governor announces a mask requirement for schools.
description: Masks will be required for teachers, staff and visitors in public and private schools, early learning programs and child care centers starting on Sept. 7.
content: Pennsylvania’s governor said on Tuesday his administration was imposing a statewide mask requirement in all schools, becoming the latest governor to embrace a politically charged but federally recommended precaution.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Treuer
title: ‘A Sadness I Can’t Carry’: The Story Of The Drum
description: For Ojibwe, the Big Drum is a gathering to mourn, to process grief, to understand loss. Could it heal my pain from the past year?
content: In the summer of 2020 I was — and there’s no fancy way​ ​to put this — falling​ ​apart. My mother died that March, just after Covid hit. My father died a few years before. Strung between the fixed poles of my parents’ deaths were the loss of my marriage, Trump’s election and the sudden and, it seemed to me, inexplicable deaths of my two best friends.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Fausset
title: New Orleanians struggle to find their footing after yet another hurricane.
description: “I don’t know what we are going to do,” one resident said. “There’s no food. And we don’t have electricity to cook.”
content: NEW ORLEANS — Nearly all of the built city survived this time. But the misery has already arrived in New Orleans, after Hurricane Ida punched up the city on Sunday night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Asfandyar Mir
title: Biden Didn’t See the ISIS-K Threat in Afghanistan Until Too Late
description: Twenty years later, the terrorism threat from Afghanistan  hasn’t faded. And militant competition from ISIS-K has merely increased the stakes.
content: When President Biden announced in the spring that America would withdraw its troops from Afghanistan by the fall, he spoke of terrorism threats — but never mentioned Islamic State Khorasan, or ISIS-K, the Islamic State’s affiliate in Afghanistan. In threat assessments about Afghanistan as late as April, the director of national intelligence, Avril Haines, barely brought up ISIS-K. On Aug. 20 Mr. Biden mentioned the group, in a speech on the last-minute effort to evacuate stranded U.S. citizens and vulnerable Afghans after the Taliban had overrun Afghanistan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina and Tariro Mzezewa
title: Ida brings more challenges for Louisiana hospitals already struggling with a Covid surge.
description: The aftermath of Hurricane Ida presented problems to some of the state’s hospitals, particularly in the shadow of the Covid-19 pandemic.
content: After Hurricane Ida lashed Louisiana on Sunday, hospitals in the storm’s path were assessing building damage, bracing for storm-related injuries and determining how to continue Covid-19 care this week, all while being forced to run on generators for at least several days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Auden Schendler
title: Worrying About Your Carbon Footprint Is Exactly What Big Oil Wants You to Do
description: The only way to really address the climate crisis is through politics, policymakers and legislation.
content: Everybody’s going carbon neutral these days, from the big boys — Amazon, Microsoft, Unilever, Starbucks, JetBlue — to your favorite outdoor brand, even ski resorts. Probably your neighborhood coffee roaster, too.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: The Buying of the American Mind
description: Government officials can be corrupted — but so can their critics.
content: Today’s column was inspired by the latest twist in our still shambolic response to Covid — the continuing refusal of many Americans to get vaccinated and the insistence of some of them on swallowing horse paste instead. I tried to link this horrifying, if comic, development to the long relationship between right-wing extremism and patent medicine. But I didn’t have space to put this in the broader context of how money influences politics and policy.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 5 Minutes That Will Make You Love the Trumpet
description: Listen to Louis Armstrong’s sweetness, Miles Davis’s wild squall, Handel’s Baroque majesty and other favorites.
content: In the past we’ve chosen the five minutes or so we would play to make our friends fall in love with classical music, piano, opera, cello, Mozart, 21st-century composers, violin, Baroque music, sopranos, Beethoven, flute, string quartets, tenors, Brahms, choral music, percussion, symphonies and Stravinsky.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Woo
title: Jury selection for the Elizabeth Holmes trial has begun.
description: Ms. Holmes is accused of misleading investors in her company, Theranos. Opening statements in the case will start next week.
content: Jury selection began on Tuesday in the long-awaited trial of Elizabeth Holmes, the disgraced founder of the blood testing start-up Theranos, who faces a dozen counts of fraud and conspiracy to commit wire fraud.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Meg St-Esprit
title: In a Fast-Moving Pandemic, Daters Are Taking It Slow
description: Looking for love demands a little more discernment in the age of Covid.
content: Since November 2020, Kerry Kijewski has been waiting to connect in person with a man she met online during Ontario, Canada’s winter lockdown. Despite the fact that he lives only 40 minutes from her London home, their dating relationship has been entirely virtual.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kwame Anthony Appiah
title: My Stepdad Has Alzheimer’s. Can My Mom Date Someone Else?
description: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on marriage vows and stolen library books.
content: What are your thoughts on the spouse of an early-onset Alzheimer’s patient dating while said patient is still alive? By way of background, my mother was the full-time caregiver of my stepfather until a few months ago, when he was moved to assisted living, and she is lonely and missing companionship. The man my mother has chosen to date is in his mid-70s (seven years older than my mother), has lost all his money, has three failed marriages and generally has a poor reputation. The way the news was broken to us children (two stepchildren, including me, and two biological children) could have been better, and we are worried our mother is acting out of fear of being alone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anahad O'Connor
title: Can Magnesium Supplements Really Help You Sleep?
description: The evidence for their sleep-inducing benefits is thin, but experts say that in some cases there’s no harm in giving them a try.
content: Magnesium is often touted as an antidote to poor sleep. But while some doctors say it is fine to take it in supplemental form for certain sleep disruptions, like those caused by restless legs syndrome, the evidence for its sleep-inducing benefits is thin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Fuller
title: What Tahoe Looks Like Right Now
description: A dispatch from the Caldor fire, which is threatening large swaths of this tourist destination and has forced thousands to evacuate.
content: SOUTH LAKE TAHOE — Sometimes you can’t help but reach for a cliché: South Lake Tahoe on Monday evening was the calm before the storm. After a frenzied mandatory evacuation that forced thousands to flee, the town went eerily still.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: Historic London Synagogue Fights to Stay Out of the Shadows
description: The 320-year-old Bevis Marks Synagogue claims that two new proposed office towers would block its sunlight and add to the sense of enclosure amid the skyscrapers of the financial district.
content: LONDON — Rabbi Shalom Morris picked his way through a steel scaffold that construction workers were noisily dismantling as he showed a visitor around his 320-year-old synagogue, Bevis Marks. When the renovation is finished, there will be a new visitors center off the snug courtyard outside the building.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley and Ben Casselman
title: The Economy Is Booming but Far From Normal, Posing a Challenge for Biden
description: High inflation, ghostly downtowns and a resurgent virus have rattled consumers and created new obstacles as the president tries to push his broader economic agenda.
content: The American economy is growing at its fastest clip in a quarter-century, yet it remains far from normal, with some workers and small-business owners facing increasingly tough times while others thrive. That divergence poses a challenge to President Biden, who has promoted the nation’s economic recovery as a selling point in his quest to win support for a multitrillion-dollar spending agenda that could cement his legacy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mansee Khurana
title: ‘Want to Join My Crossword Group Chat?’
description: A new generation of crossword enthusiasts has changed the way that puzzles are discussed. And they are determined to make their pastime a space where all are welcome.
content: On a typical school day, Lila Goldenberg rarely gets a chance to chat with her friends about her hobbies. But when Ms. Goldenberg, 15, a high school student in Los Angeles, is able to find some time to log onto Reddit, she finds exactly what she’s looking for: a community of people who can’t wait to discuss their opinions on the latest crossword puzzles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Your Wednesday Briefing
description: Biden defends Afghanistan decisions.
content: A day after the final transport plane carrying American forces left the Kabul airport, President Biden hailed what he called the “extraordinary success” of the evacuation as he strongly defended his decision to end the U.S. war in Afghanistan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Colin
title: It’s Never Too Late to Ditch the City and Run a Farm
description: Martha Prewitt performed as an opera singer for 15 years. But passions wane. She now runs the family farm in Kentucky, singing arias to cattle and corn. Sometimes bugs fly into her mouth.
content: “It’s Never Too Late” is a new series that tells the stories of people who decide to pursue their dreams on their own terms.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: How the Delta Variant Spread From a Teacher to Half of Her Students
description: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, August 31, 2021.
content: “If teacher has no mask, move to the back of the class.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacey Fortin, Johnny Diaz and Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: Ida moves north, threatening an already soaked Tennessee.
description: The remnants of the hurricane were expected to bring stormy conditions across a large part of the U.S. in the next few days.
content: The remnants of Hurricane Ida were expected to bring stormy conditions to a large swath of the United States, from Tennessee to Massachusetts, over the next few days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Penn and Peter Eavis
title: Entergy’s Push to Restore Power in Louisiana Is Slowed by Downed Lines
description: The utility said on Monday that Hurricane Ida had put 216 substations and more than 2,000 miles of transmission lines out of service.
content: Two days after Hurricane Ida arrived in Southern Louisiana, hundreds of thousands of homes and businesses remained without power and many could stay that way for weeks as crews work to restore downed power lines belonging to Entergy, the largest utility in the state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. David Goodman, Nick Corasaniti and Reid J. Epstein
title: Texas G.O.P. Passes Election Bill, Raising Voting Barriers Even Higher
description: The bill, which will tighten what were already some of the nation’s strictest voting rules, represents a major victory for Republicans in their nationwide push to overhaul elections.
content: HOUSTON — The Republican-controlled Texas Legislature on Tuesday passed a major bill overhauling the state’s elections, overcoming a six-week walkout by Democrats to cement Texas as one of the most difficult states in the country in which to vote.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter S. Goodman
title: Hurricane Ida could make the supply chain disaster even worse.
description: Shortages in construction materials are likely to delay the efforts to rebuild in the aftermath of the devastating storm.
content: In normal times, the devastation of a massive hurricane like Ida tends to be followed by an aggressive rebuilding effort, as carpenters, roofers and other skilled workers descend on affected communities to repair the damage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eshe Nelson
title: Private Equity Firms All Want the Same Thing: British Companies
description: Flush with capital, the funds have gone bargain hunting in Britain, snapping up everything from supermarkets to defense companies.
content: LONDON — It began as a market stall in West Yorkshire, selling eggs and butter just before the turn of the 20th century.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin Pogrebin
title: Four Powerful Art Dealers Join Forces, Upending Traditional Model
description: Dominique Lévy, Brett Gorvy, Amalia Dayan and Jeanne Greenberg Rohatyn will become LGDR, a one-stop shop for artists and collectors.
content: In one of the strongest signs yet that the art market will not look the same after the pandemic — and in an apparent effort to counter the increasing dominance of mega galleries — four prominent dealers have made the unorthodox decision to consolidate under one roof.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Jacobs
title: 180 cases are traced to a church camp and conference that didn’t require vaccinations or testing, the C.D.C. says.
description: No deaths have been linked the two events in organized by an Illinois church group, but five people have been hospitalized, all of them unvaccinated.
content: At least 180 coronavirus infections in three states have been traced to an Illinois church camp for teenagers and an affiliated men’s conference that did not require attendees to be vaccinated or tested for the virus, according to an investigation published on Tuesday by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Tempus
title: When Climate Change Comes to Your Doorstep
description: Climate migration is here. Where we go next is unclear.
content: There was not enough time to fully evacuate New Orleans before Hurricane Ida hit. The hurricane intensified too rapidly. Thousands who could flee, did. Mayor LaToya Cantrell urged those left behind, including many without the money or resources to pack up and go, to “hunker down.” The storm tore off roofs and wiped out power.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sapna Maheshwari
title: Allbirds’s I.P.O. filing shows losses but grand ambitions for its sustainable shoes.
description: The company, which brought in about $219 million in revenue last year, posted losses for the last two years, and it expects more losses to come.
content: Allbirds, the maker of wool sneakers, offered a long-awaited peek at its earnings when its filing for an initial public offering was made public on Tuesday, revealing strong digital sales in 2020 despite an annual loss.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: The End
description: America’s longest war is over.
content: After the attack on Pearl Harbor in 1941, the United States and its allies needed less than four years to vanquish their fascist enemies. After the secession of Southern states in 1860 and 1861, the U.S. spent slightly more than four years defeating the rebellion. After the first battles at Lexington and Concord in 1775, the colonies took about eight years to beat the British and create a new nation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport and Margot Sanger-Katz
title: Social Security is projected to be insolvent a year earlier than previously forecast.
description: Annual government reports on the solvency of the programs underscored the questions about the long-term viability of Social Security and Medicare.
content: The financial outlook for Social Security is eroding more quickly than previously expected, as the coronavirus pandemic has drained government revenues and put additional strain on one of the nation’s most important social safety net programs. The overall finances for Medicare, however, are expected to hold steady, though the health program is still forecast to face financial pressure in the coming years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katy Reckdahl, J. David Goodman and Edgar Sandoval
title: In Louisiana, Rescue Workers Search for Those Stranded by Hurricane Ida
description: More than a million people, including most in New Orleans, were without electricity, but the city’s levees held.
content: NEW ORLEANS — Rescue teams fanned out across Louisiana on Monday searching for people left stranded in the aftermath of Hurricane Ida, even as New Orleans emerged from its most serious onslaught since Hurricane Katrina confident that its levees had held.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Grace Ashford
title: Hochul directs $65 million for booster shots in New York if federal regulators approve them.
description: Gov. Kathy Hochul, who was sworn in as governor last Tuesday, has made clear that fighting the Delta variant is her top priority,
content: Gov. Kathy Hochul of New York announced new measures on Tuesday designed to beat back the Delta variant of the coronavirus, including the allocation of $65 million to local health departments for the rollout of booster shots, assuming federal regulators clear them, and a plan to broaden vaccine requirements in schools and state regulated facilities.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Transcript: Ezra Klein Answers Listener Questions
description: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, but today Ezra is being interviewed: he’s answering listener questions. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
content: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, but today Ezra is being interviewed: he’s answering listener questions. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: HOWM Cocina & Cocktails Opens in Chelsea
description: A gastropub with a fine-dining consultant, a Korean barbecue restaurant featuring beef ribs and more restaurant news.
content: The name is pronounced “home.” Remembering how it’s spelled is something else. The idea, according to the Gilded Group, which manages the restaurant in partnership with the Selina Chelsea hotel, is to express people coming together with food and drink. Got that? What the name doesn’t reflect is the nature of the food and drink, a focused exploration of Mexico, Central America and South America. (The hotel is part of a chain with a strong presence in Central America and Mexico.) The chef, Byron Peñafiel, a native of Ecuador, takes some liberties with tradition: His small plates include pupusas with curtido (a kind of cabbage slaw), charred octopus with jalapeño hummus, and grilled broccolini in a mole sauce. Large dishes are guava-glazed roasted chicken, aged churrasco (rib-eye for two) with chimichurri, and chaulafan (Ecuadorean fried rice) chicharrone using black rice, seafood, pork rinds and salsa verde. Deep-fried plantains (patacones) are served for the table, complimentary. Gilded Group’s beverage director, Daniel Bedoya, who was raised in Ecuador, has devised an array of cocktails. These are served in the airy ground-floor restaurant with yellow accents that has outdoor terrace seating on two levels, and also at the 10th-floor Rooftop at Selina Chelsea with expansive views and a plunge pool. (Opens Wednesday)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: Colm Toibin’s ‘The Magician’ Intimately Recaptures a Literary Giant
description: In his latest novel, Toibin imagines the life of Thomas Mann, the Nobel Prize-winning author of “The Magic Mountain” and “Death in Venice.”
content: Thomas Mann’s long and permanent exile from Germany began in 1933, after Hitler came to power, when the author of “Death in Venice” and “The Magic Mountain” fled to Switzerland along with Katia, his Jewish wife. When World War II erupted six years later, the Manns escaped to the United States, first to Princeton and then to Los Angeles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: Maxime Cressy, an American qualifier, delivers the biggest upset so far.
description: Maxime Cressy, an American qualifier, produced the biggest upset so far of this year’s U.S. Open. Playing with a throwback serve-and-volley style and big-point panache, Cressy rallied from two sets down in the first round to defeat No. 9-seeded Pablo Carreño Busta in a fifth-set tiebreaker.
content: Maxime Cressy, an American qualifier, produced the biggest upset so far of this year’s U.S. Open. Playing with a throwback serve-and-volley style and big-point panache, Cressy rallied from two sets down in the first round to defeat No. 9-seeded Pablo Carreño Busta in a fifth-set tiebreaker.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Priya Krishna
title: The Shy Sisters Behind Austin’s Breakout Breakfast Tacos
description: From a single food truck to its coming expansion to Los Angeles, Veracruz All Natural has won a huge following. Yet its owners are still striving to attract more Hispanic diners.
content: AUSTIN, Texas — It was early morning in the lobby of the Line Hotel, and everyone was eating migas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carol Rosenberg
title: Three Guantánamo Detainees Charged in 2002 Bali Bombing
description: The men were brought to court for the first time 18 years after their capture and after a one-day delay because of translation challenges at the war court.
content: GUANTÁNAMO BAY, Cuba — Three men who have been detained by the United States for 18 years without charge were formally accused of war crimes on Tuesday as part of a global Qaeda conspiracy that began in Afghanistan in 1996 and resulted in the grisly Bali nightclub bombings in 2002.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Nolen
title: An Experimental H.I.V. Vaccine Fails in Africa
description: Researchers ended a large trial in South Africa after finding that an experimental vaccine offered little protection.
content: An advanced H.I.V. vaccine trial in Africa has been shut down after data showed the shots offered only limited protection against the virus, researchers announced on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Phillips
title: Wall Street Sees Nothing but Good News, Even When It’s Bad
description: With expectations that interest rates will stay down and government spending will stay up, the stock market has learned to live with the pandemic, even as cases increase.
content: Bad news doesn’t seem to bother Wall Street these days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: The police set up checkpoints outside New Zealand’s largest city.
description: The aim is to limit travel out of Auckland, which will remain under the highest level of Covid restrictions for two weeks after rules are eased in neighboring regions.
content: The police in New Zealand are establishing checkpoints south of Auckland, the country’s largest city, to prevent people from moving illegally between regions with different levels of virus restrictions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah E. Bromwich
title: Instagram User @AntiVaxMomma Charged With Selling Fake Vaccine Cards
description: The charges highlight how a black market for counterfeit Covid-19 vaccine cards has grown as the Delta variant fuels the latest wave of the coronavirus.
content: A New Jersey woman who used the Instagram handle @AntiVaxMomma was charged in a conspiracy to sell hundreds of fake coronavirus vaccination cards over the social media platform, Manhattan prosecutors said on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher
title: G.O.P. Governors Fight Mandates as the Party’s Covid Politics Harden
description: As several Republican-controlled states confront their worst outbreaks yet, their leaders — following the base — have doubled down on resisting vaccine and mask requirements.
content: As a new coronavirus wave accelerated by the Delta variant spreads across the United States, many Republican governors have taken sweeping action to combat what they see as an even more urgent danger posed by the pandemic: the threat to personal freedom.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Seth Colter Walls
title: For Music, a Fall Deluge of Performances Is Beginning
description: Summer has been quiet, but the weekend brought some brilliant concerts. (Delta variant be damned.)
content: The summertime classical calendar tends to be light even under normal circumstances — so during a lingering pandemic, it can seem almost nonexistent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Spencer Bokat-Lindell
title: The Red Tape That Could Cost Millions of Americans Their Homes
description: Congress allocated enough money to stave off a wave of evictions, but it's not being sent to renters fast enough.
content: This article is part of the Debatable newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it on Tuesdays and Thursdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elian Peltier
title: 70 percent of adults in the European Union have been fully vaccinated.
description: After a fumbling start, the European Union overtook the United States in vaccinations last month.
content: Around 70 percent of adults in the European Union have been fully vaccinated against the coronavirus, E.U. officials said on Tuesday, a milestone that puts the bloc among the world’s leaders in vaccinations despite a sluggish start earlier this year and worrying discrepancies among member states.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamie Feldmar
title: For a Late-Summer Gathering, Try This Spin on a Salade Niçoise
description: Fanny Singer takes some liberties with her version of the classic dish, going so far as to include lettuce.
content: “Lettuce is not typically found in a salade niçoise — it’s sacrilege,” says the writer and art critic Fanny Singer. “But I’ll sneak lettuce into every meal.” It’s a fitting act of rebellion for the daughter of the chef and restaurateur Alice Waters, the owner of Berkeley’s legendary temple to local produce, Chez Panisse. Meanwhile, Singer’s father, Stephen Singer, owns a vineyard in Sebastopol, Calif.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joanne Kaufman
title: For a Tony Nominee, an Apartment With a Sense of Drama
description: Kathryn Gallagher’s Upper West Side home ‘was never supposed to be a one-bedroom apartment.’ But that’s why she likes it.
content: When Kathryn Gallagher was 11, the career demands of her father, the actor Peter Gallagher, forced the family to leave the Upper West Side of Manhattan for Los Angeles. A decade or so later, the demands of her own burgeoning career — specifically, a role in the 2015 Broadway revival of “Spring Awakening” — meant a move back to Manhattan. And she knew precisely where she wanted to land.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shayla Martin
title: What to Do This Summer: Washington, D.C.
description: In the nation’s capital, the walkable neighborhoods of Logan Circle, West End/Foggy Bottom and Dupont Circle are showing off new restaurants with tons of outdoor dining, shops and galleries.
content: Whether they work on or off Capitol Hill, Washingtonians tend to plan their summer schedules around that of Congress, meaning that during the weeks preceding the lawmakers’ return (this year beginning in mid-September), the nation’s capital is far less crowded than usual. For visitors, a largely empty city means the possibility of scoring reservations at the most exclusive restaurants and strolling past the glowing Lincoln Memorial at night without joggers ruining your photo op.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caroline Chen
title: How to Solve Any Problem Using Just Common Sense
description: Contemplating Fermi problems keeps me curious about the world and how things relate to one another.
content: Whenever I got stuck on math homework while growing up, I would go looking for my mother. Often I would find her on the living-room couch unwinding after work, catching up on the news with both the local Cantonese news station blaring on the TV and The Economist open in her lap.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder
title: College Football Changes: More 2-Point Tries and a Crackdown on Stadium Gamesmanship
description: Officials made some tweaks to the rule book for 2021. Next year, though, could bring much more rewriting.
content: With all of the changes around college sports this year — players making money off their fame, new policies on transferring and an eased-up approach to the coronavirus pandemic — perhaps it seemed impossible to squeeze more tweaks into 2021.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Proulx
title: Reflections on Our Summer Reading Contest and Our Final Week of Winners
description: Thoughts from our judges on our 12th annual contest, and two winning essays from Gabriel and Weihan (Lily) Chen.
content: For the past 10 weeks, we have invited teenagers from around the world to tell us what they were reading, watching and listening to in The New York Times and why it caught their attention.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: The final moments of the U.S. presence in Afghanistan.
content: The last U.S. forces left Afghanistan late last night, ending a 20-year occupation that began shortly after Sept. 11, cost over $2 trillion, took more than 170,000 lives and ultimately failed to defeat the Taliban, the Islamist militants who allowed Al Qaeda to operate there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noel Murray
title: The Best Movies and TV Shows Coming to Amazon, HBO, Hulu and More in September
description: Every month, streaming services add movies and TV shows to its library. Here are our favorites for September.
content: Every month, streaming services add movies and TV shows to its library. Here are our picks for some of September’s most promising new titles. (Note: Streaming services occasionally change schedules without giving notice. For more recommendations on what to stream, sign up for our Watching newsletter here.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Winston Choi-Schagrin
title: As a preview of future hurricanes, Ida is ‘very scary.’
description: There is broad consensus among scientists that a warming climate will lead to more extreme and heavy rainfall during storms, as Hurricane Ida is illustrating.
content: The effects of Hurricane Ida will be felt far from where it made landfall in southern Louisiana on Sunday. As it moves across the Upper Ohio Valley and toward the Northeast later in the week, it is likely to cause heavy downpours, including up to 10 inches of rain in some parts of the Mid-Atlantic. More than 80 million Americans were under a flood watch or advisory, with the majority associated with Ida’s heavy rains.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John McWhorter
title: Let’s Talk About ‘Sellouts’
description: The insult that reveals a flaw in the way we talk about race.
content: When I published my first book about race, in 2000, one of the oddest things I encountered was that many people thought — and I mean, actually supposed — that the reason I was airing my “contrarian” views about race was to make money.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gwen Knapp
title: For These Paralympians, a Pursuit of Excellence Means Life Abroad
description: The United States may be the birthplace of basketball, but to make a career out of playing wheelchair hoops, athletes have had to move overseas.
content: TOKYO — To play wheelchair basketball for a living, members of the U.S. Paralympic men’s team have put their passports through vigorous workouts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kathryn Harrison
title: In Lauren Groff’s New Novel, Nothing — and Everything — Is Sacred
description: “Matrix” tells the life story of an orphan who is cast out of the royal court and put in charge of an impoverished abbey.
content: MATRIXBy Lauren Groff
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Shpigel and Ken Belson
title: Patriots Cut Cam Newton After Covid-Related Disruptions
description: Newton was sidelined early last season with the virus and missed practices last week because of a mix-up over protocols. The rookie quarterback Mac Jones will be New England’s starter.
content: After entering training camp as New England’s starting quarterback, Cam Newton didn’t just lose that job on Tuesday — he lost his roster spot, too.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Whet Moser
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: The partisan divide over school mandates widens.
content: The fight over masks and vaccines is heating up —  especially between President Biden and the governors who hope to defeat him in 2024. Many Republicans see the rules as a threat to their personal freedom that is more dangerous than the coronavirus itself.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennie Erin Smith and Federico Rios
title: Searching for Bird Life in a Former ‘Ocean of Forest’
description: A century after museum collectors surveyed Colombia’s avian fauna, a new generation of researchers returns to see what remains, and what has changed.
content: FLORENCIA, Colombia — In June 1912, Leo Miller, a collector with the American Museum of Natural History, arrived in the Caquetá region of Colombia, where the eastern foothills of the Andes melt into the forested lowlands of the Amazon basin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: An alligator attacked a Louisiana man in an area flooded by Ida.
description: A woman told deputies that she saw a large alligator attacking her husband outside their residence on Monday.
content: A Louisiana man was missing and presumed dead after an alligator attacked him on Monday in an area that was flooded during Hurricane Ida, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Fuller, Livia Albeck-Ripka and Max Whittaker
title: To Save Lake Tahoe, They Spared No Expense. The Fire Came Over the Ridge Anyway.
description: Experts believe that the challenge is a cautionary tale for future megafires in the West and lays bare a certain futility in trying to fully control the most aggressive wildfires.
content: SOUTH LAKE TAHOE, Calif. — They sent thousands of firefighters, 25 helicopters and an arsenal of more than 400 fire engines and 70 water trucks. Yet the fire still advanced.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein and Michelle Agins
title: Fans waited an extra year for the U.S. Open. Then they waited some more.
description: As the first tennis balls were struck in earnest at the U.S. Open on Monday
content: As the first tennis balls were struck in earnest at the U.S. Open on Monday, thousands of frustrated tennis fans waited patiently to get inside for the first time in two years, stuck in a human traffic jam that left many feeling angry and sick in the hot sun.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Drape
title: A Dedicated Horsewoman Leaves No Thoroughbred Behind
description: Jessica Paquette has built a busy life as a handicapper, an analyst, an equestrian and a friend to retired racehorses.
content: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y. — Jessica Paquette calls herself a “weird horse girl.” She was 6 when she was first entranced by them, at a New England fair. They were so big, but gentle enough for her to reach up and rub their noses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: Do Republicans Actually Want the Pandemic to End?
description: It sure doesn’t feel that way sometimes.
content: President Barack Obama promised unity. In his 2008 campaign, he said he would heal the nation’s political divides and end more than a decade of partisan rancor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael M. Grynbaum, Nicole Sperling and Julia Jacobs
title: Mike Richards Is Out as ‘Jeopardy!’ Executive Producer
description: Three weeks after naming him as Alex Trebek’s replacement to host the show, Sony cited “disruption and internal difficulties” in its announcement that he will leave the program entirely.
content: Sony said on Tuesday that Mike Richards would immediately exit his job as the executive producer of “Jeopardy!,” completing a stunning downfall for a game-show impresario who just three weeks ago had secured one of the most coveted jobs in television as the replacement for the longtime host Alex Trebek.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: TUESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Malia Wollan
title: How to Collect Crystals
description: Wear jeans and bring along a small pickax. Expect crowds, but don’t worry — crystal enthusiasts tend to be a genial, family-friendly lot.
content: “If you’re looking for crystals, Arkansas is the best in the world,” says Bryan Major, 43, a self-described rock hound from Wilmington, N.C., who spends much of the year traveling the country digging for minerals, gems and crystals. His YouTube videos documenting his outings have been viewed more than 57 million times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dror Poleg
title: Working remotely has meant huge salaries, for a lucky few.
description: Who wins and who loses when companies can hire from anywhere?
content: Who wins and who loses when companies can hire from anywhere?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tara Haelle
title: This Is the Moment the Anti-Vaccine Movement Has Been Waiting For
description: Anti-vaccine activists are more politically savvy and dangerous than ever before.
content: As the coronavirus began pushing the nation into lockdown in March 2020, Joshua Coleman, an anti-vaccine campaigner who organizes anti-vaccine rallies, went on Facebook Live to give his followers a rallying speech. He laid out what he thought the pandemic really was: an opportunity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rasheed
title: I Worked With the U.S. in Afghanistan. I Thought I Would Be Saved.
description: Thousands of Afghans like me had their hopes for escape from the Taliban dashed when the U.S. completed its withdrawal.
content: When the last U.S. plane left Afghanistan, celebratory Taliban gunfire rang out through the night in Kabul. The sound told me that all hope was lost.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Rockefellers vs. Exxon, the Company That Made Them
description: The family that pioneered the oil industry in America wants to expose what Exxon hid from the public about climate change.
content: The family that pioneered the oil industry in America wants to expose what Exxon hid from the public about climate change.

author: By The New York Times
title: Biden Says, ‘The War in Afghanistan Is Now Over’
description: President Biden defended his decision to end the 20-year war in Afghanistan, a day after the U.S. closed a two-week evacuation of 125,000 people from Kabul that saw the deaths of 13 American service members.

author: By Reuters
title: Blinken: A ‘Diplomatic Mission’ Has Begun in Afghanistan
description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken said fewer than 200 Americans were still in Afghanistan, pledging safe passage for them and assistance for Afghans who were at risk of reprisal for working with the U.S. government.
content: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken said fewer than 200 Americans were still in Afghanistan, pledging safe passage for them and assistance for Afghans who were at risk of reprisal for working with the U.S. government.

author: By Storyful and Associated Press
title: Ida Causes Flooding and Washes Out a Mississippi Highway
description: The storm, which moved into Mississippi as a powerful hurricane before being downgraded to a tropical depression, washed away part of a major highway, causing at least two deaths.
content: The storm, which moved into Mississippi as a powerful hurricane before being downgraded to a tropical depression, washed away part of a major highway, causing at least two deaths.

title: Hochul Outlines Measures to Combat the Delta Variant
description: Gov. Kathy Hochul of New York said she would institute a school mask mandate, pursue vaccination or mandatory testing requirements for school staff and allocate $65 million for the rollout of booster shots after federal regulators clear them.

title: Corrections: Aug. 31, 2021
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, Aug. 31, 2021.
content: An article on Sunday about U.S. veterans who are acting as digital guides to Americans and Afghans trying to flee Afghanistan misidentified a project manager from North Carolina who had served in the Marines. He is Rich Porter, not Phil.
